Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, spreadsheets glowing in the dim light. My stepson, Ethan, bounced into the room, eyes bright with hope. “Are we getting the Nintendo this weekend?” he asked, voice full of trust. I remembered the promise I’d made—one I knew meant the world to him. But as I glanced at my phone, a reminder popped up: project planning call in ten minutes. My manager expected me to join, to give precise estimates for the new design phase. The team was counting on my input, even if the session was informal and the timeline still flexible. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. Ethan’s expectant gaze tugged at my heart, but the numbers on my screen reminded me of our tight budget. I needed to show up for my family, to keep us secure, but I also needed to be present for my team. My mind raced, torn between the promise I’d made at home and the responsibility I carried at work, unsure which demand to answer first.
